problem.p: This is a concept question, provided to check your understanding of the previous video clip.
Prof. Harrow presented some example density matrices in lecture; which of the following statements about such density matrices [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline] are true?

choice.text: The diagonal entries [mathjaxinline]\rho _{kk}[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline] represent probabilities of measurements resulting in the [mathjaxinline]k^{\rm th}[/mathjaxinline] eigenstate of [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline]

The diagonal entries [mathjaxinline]\rho _{kk}[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline] represent the probabilities of measurements resulting basis element [mathjaxinline]|k\rangle[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]\rho[/mathjaxinline]
The density matrix for a qubit is [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] and has four real degrees of freedom
The density matrix for a qubit is [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] and has three real degrees of freedom
The [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] identity matrix (divided by two) is a qubit density matrix represented by a point at the center of the Bloch sphere
The [mathjaxinline]2\times 2[/mathjaxinline] identity matrix (divided by two) is a qubit density matrix represented by a point at the north pole of the Bloch sphere
